Zt will be a surprise to anyone to receive a letter from somebody whom you do not know and it will be more to you if you will al low me to inroduce myself as just Ralph. Maybe you are wonder ing now who am I. My name is Rafael M. Atencio of a large city in the Philippines. JI am thirteen years old and second year in the high school when the war broke Mrs. J street, ou . I am a son of a dentist in were the city, which was once a beauti ful city in the Orient. My pur pose in sending you this letter is to convey to you all in America how the Filipino boys feel proud of your soldiers where your son, Stratton Franklin belongs. I, as all o her Filipinos feel the grati tude we owe to your beloved country as a genuine liberator of our beloved Philippines from the tentacles of the wily oc opus-like Japan, which sucked the blood and life of our race and crumpled be yond human, endurance the tem- . t red-steel -like patience of the Filipino people. It is but human for me otherwise, not if I not express the, burning seniment from my heart the real apprecia tion of a true Filipino toward the realization and importance of Feb ruary, 1945, which marked the date in the page of the Philippine his ory the sudden victorious thrust of the American forces in the city against the Japanese. It wao abou five oclock P. M. day light saving time, when the first bursting of bombs land bullets heralded the victorious thrust o f the American forces in this city thus the dark clouds of uncertain ty that covered over here for al most four years has been torn in to new dawns of hopes. We have now a real new life! Especially now I have many new and lovely American friends, veiiy kind sol diers they are. One is your dear est ion, Who requested me to write to you. I wish I could be be with him in America! He is in the best of health without a scar nor a scratch, because they al ways won the battle! Let iis pray for them all to win to Victory!

document.text: Zack Elliott Cheatham, 82, of Evergreen hid Tuesday, July 4,19TB in Medferi Care Center inIA 6 hhucg HI Bora in Appomattox County, he was a son of the late James Hudson, and MoUy Evans Chetttham. R t v u a farmer and dealer in cattle and horses and member of the Virginia Horse Show Association. He is survived by his wife, Mayme Chocklett Cheatham a son, James Elliott Cheatham of Clearwater, Fla. a daughter, Jeanne C. Stanley of Appomat tox two sisters, Annie C. Bingham of Lynchburg and Alice C. Babcock of Columbia. S.C. four grandchildren, Zack and Nan Cheatham of Clear water, Fla., and Bill and Jan Stanley of Appomattox, and a great-grandson, James Hudson Cheatham of Clearwater, Fla. Besides the immediate fam ily, there were present a niece, Mrs. Anne Branmgan. and husband from California a nephew. Cecil Robbins, and wife from Wilmington, N. O. and a nephew, Huck Babcock, from Columbia, S. C. and many cousins. Funeral services were con ducted at 130 p.m. Friday from Robinson Funeral Home m Appomattox. Burial was m Evergreen Cemetery. Serving as pall bearers were Jack Baker, David Paulette, Kermit Paulette, Edward Har vey, Leslie Goodrich, Jesse Franklin, Herbert Diadmond, and Henry Simmons.

document.text: Z. V. Harvey and J. R. Hamilton are on the sick list this week. Deepest sympathy is extended to C. W. Carrico and family. Mrs. O. C. Paulette is spending a few days this week with her son, J. E. Paulette, of Madison Heights. Her daughter-in-law is a patient at Virginia Baptist Hospital. Mr. and Mrs. R. E. Harris spent Sunday evening at Spout Spring. Dinner guests Sunday in the home of Mr. and Mrs. C. J. Paulette were Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Hawk and family and Eva Martin, of Hix- burg and Mr. and Mrs. Jessie Franklin and family,

YOUR MONEY FLIES! Fnsi enough when you buy clothing at the lowest prices then why take chances by buying from concerns that ask more for goods than they are worth. Is it not evident that when you are asked 12 for a suit which you finally buy for 10, that the at- empt was made to get 2 of your money for nothing! and is it not probable that the next fellow pays only 8 for the same suit? ONE PRICE TO ALL, CASH TO ALL, is the sea on which this business was launched two years ago. We have had most favorable winds in the form of public appre ciation of Fair Dealing and Lowest Prices, and shall continue to sail under the same flag, never asking more than the value of goods, and always asking less than any two- priccd or credit-giving house can afford. SHEARER BROTHERS  FRANKLIN, 908 M A IN STREET. LYNCHBURGS ONLY ONE PRICE CASH CLOTHIERS.

document.text: young person or an older person, could possibly be using drugs, he advised that you look for a change in personality, change in the persons outlook, in values and in appearance. Franklin expressed his opin ion in the fact that alcohol abuse is our number one problem, drugs come second. He feels that with cooperation and interest of concerned citizens the drug problem can be controlled but not the alcohol problem. In deeding with young people, perhaps your own children, he suggested that you really get to know them, take them places, lie to them and listen to what they have to say, and know where your children are when they go out. Lots of kids turn to drugs simply to get attention from parents. Dont be guilty of this situation. A slide presentation showed different types of drugs and the Investigator spoke about their reactions. He stressed that the most important thing to always remember is when a person boys drugs on the street, he never knows just what he is getting. Sometimes it is too late as you buy what you think is clean marijuana and never know the fifferene until you have used it.  .then it la too late. You could find yourself in a hospital with brain damage or it could even kill you. Following the Drug Identifi cation Program, a question and answer portion of the program followed. On the panel to answer questions were Sam Kerr, Appomattox Common wealths Attorney Lloyd G. Walton, Appomattox County School Superintendent Gene Continued on Page 2

document.text: You can look at me and see Ben Franklin walking down the streets of Philadelphia with his breadloaf under his arm. You can see Betsy Ross with her needle. You can see the lights of Christmas, and hear the strains of Auld Lang Syne as the calendar turns. I am Babe Ruth and the World Series. I am 169,000 schools and colleges, and 250,000 churches where my people worship God as they think best. I am a ballot dropped in a box, the roar of a crowd in a stadium, and the voice of a choir in a cathedral. I am an editorial in a newspaper, and a letter to a Congressman. I am Eli Whitney and Stephen Foster. I am Tom Edison, Albert Einstein and Billy Graham. I am Horace Greeley, Will Rogers, and the W right brothers. I am G eorge W ashington Carver, Daniel W ebster and Jonas Salk. Yes, I am the nation, and these are the things that I am. I was conceived in freedom and, God willing, in freedom I will spend the rest of my days. May I possess always the integrity, the courage and the strength to keep myself unshackled, to remain a citadel of freedom and a beacon of hope to the world. This is my wish , my goal, my prayer on July 4, 1955 one hundred and seventy-nine years after I was born.

text.snippet: me and see Ben <mark>Franklin</mark> walking down the streets

highlights.snippet: me and see Ben <mark>Franklin</mark> walking down the streets

document.text: You can look at me and see Ben Franklin walking down the streets of Philadelphia with his breadloaf under his arm. You can see Betsy Ross with her needle. You can see the lights o f Christmas, and hear the strains of Auld Lang Syne as the calendar turns. I am Babe Ruth and the World Series. I am 169,000 schools and colleges, and 250,000 churches where my people worship God as they think best. I am a ballot dropped in a box, the roar of a crowd in a stadium, and the voice o f a choir in a cathedral. I am an editorial in a newspaper, and a letter to a Congressman. I am Eli Whitney and Stephen Foster. I am Tom Edison, Albert Einstein and Billy Graham. I am Horace Greeley, Will Rogers, and the Wright brothers. I am George W ashington Carver, Daniel Webster and Jonas Salk. Yes, I am the nation, and these are the things that I am. I was conceived in freedom and, God willing, in freedom I will spend the rest of my days. May I possess always the integrity, the courage and the strength to keep myself unshackled, to remain a citadel of freedom and a beacon o f hope to the world. This is my wish, my goal, my prayer on July 4, 1957  one hundred and eighty-one years after l was born.

document.text: You are invited to Attend Springfield Baptist Church on Sunday, May 25,1980 to help celebrate Family and Friends Day. Foster A. Lewis, sponsor and Cora Pankey, co-spon sor, are former residents of Appomattox Rev. Franklin Blackman, pastor of Zion Hill Baptist Church Baltimore, Maryland will be the 11 a.m. and 3 p.m. speaker. His congregation will accompany him. Please mark your calen dar. Dont miss these sendees. A dynamic pro gram has been planned for you. God Blest each of you.

document.text: You are cordially invited to the regular preaching service, at Zion Baptist Church Sunday, May 4 at 11. a.m. The Male Chofus is having its second anniversary Sun day, May 4 at 3 p.m. at Zion Baptist. The. Senior- Usher Board met Sunday at 11 a.m. with vice president Barbara Hunter calling the meeting to order. Our chaplain, Mr. Waverly Gray was in charge of the devotion. Mrs. Nannie Johnson, recording secre tary, took minutes. The Usher Board is planning for their anniver sary the second Sunday .in June. You are cordially invited to our Mothers Dfcy program on the second Sunday in May at 11 a.m. Our guest speaker will be the. Rev. H. O. Flood, and the Male Chorus will perform. It is sponsored by the Ladies Aid. Mrs. G. Ws Wiggins will be the M.C. The deaconess second anni- verary was a success at the Zion Baptist Church Sunday. Rev. Charles Lewis and the choir from Amherst were the guetoia Our sympathy goes out to the Snell and Williams family in the loss of their joved one, Mr. Aubrey Snell. We are praying for Our Sick everywhere. . Mrs. Romaine Lipscomb, Mrs. Pinky Davis, Mrs. Maude Lipscomb, Rev. Rob ert Jones and his mother, Mrs. Mary Belle Miller, all of Cumberland County and, also. Rev. Samuel Terry and Rev. Charles Rice of Lynchburg, all visited Mrs. Magnolia Franklin ip her home recently. I Misses Sybil and Cindy Franklin recently spent a few. days in Bluefield, W. Va., with their relatives and friends.

text.snippet: all visited Mrs. Magnolia <mark>Franklin</mark> ip her home recently.

highlights.snippet: all visited Mrs. Magnolia <mark>Franklin</mark> ip her home recently.

document.text: You are cordially invited to regular preaching service to be held at the Zion Baptist Church Sunday at 11 a.m. with Rev. Charles Lewis. The Vacation Bible School was a success, which was held at the Zion Baptist Church last week. 11 present enjoyed the pro gram held at the Zion Baptist Church last Sunday. With Rodney- Allen . and concert from Lynchburg at 4 p.m. All the sick are improving. Let us all pray for our sick and shut-in. Out-of-town guests in the. Franklins home recently were Mrs. Helen Patterson of Washington, D.C., Mr. and Mrs. Claude Cobbs and their two children. They are visiting Mr. Cobbs mother, Mrs. Minnie Cobbs and friends-, Mrs. Franklin is happy to have her daughter, B.B.

It is expected that there will be other additions by baptism and by letter. At the evening hour, the pastor will preach for the Rev. T. Sloan Guy at Franklin St. Church, Lynchburg and Rev. 1 0000000000000 Mr. Perkihs, of Lynchburg, will preach at Liberty. Mr. Guy is engaged in Revival meetings in Halifax County.

document.text: You a rt cordially invited to attend the regular preaching .service at the Zion Baptist Church Sunday at 11 a.m. The speaker for the hour will be Rev. Charles Lewis from Madison Heights. The Senior choir will have its regular meeting Friday night at 7 p.m. The Senior Usher Board meet m   1 I t a.m. with vice pi sst Miss Barbara Hun te r. Mrs. Nannie Johnson recording secretary, Mrs. Mag nolia Franklin was in charge of the devotions. The minutes w ere read, received and adopted. Dues taken. The meeting was opened for new and old business. Mrs. Nannie Johnson gave some very helpful remarks to our board. -After which our m eeting -adjourned for next month. Our sympathy goes to the family of Mr. Westmore Wheeler. Mrs. Mildred Wheeler is very sick in Lynchburg General Hospital. We are praying for our sick everywhere. Mr. Ed Mosley is home doing nicely. Mr. Frank Robertson and Mrs. Odell Hix is doing very well. Miss Mary C. Brown is on the sick list.

document.text: yonng married oonple, who hav- been housekeeping in Washington and they tell me their table supplie for a month cost only sixteen do Jars. Nor did they live on scraps, bat fed on many luxuries. Th good wife learned, when a girl, iron mother how to cook and with a gs stove with three burners, she pre pare! the meals, and the good ma of the house said  fine. And know that good man, and that oats for one meal what would do me for fonr. Of conrae they bough prudently, and kept aloof from  soiety, as Sam Jones called They did, however, entertain friend now and then and gave them meals of whicu they v. ere not ashamed Panl Jones, of Sheppards, once said to me, I am the only Metho 1st, out of a family of twelve, the rest having strayed off tu the Pies by ter i ans. And I have found an other who makes me the same state ment. Paul, steadfast to the foitb of the fathers, and tbe others stray- era. Sounds queer, doesnt it? lint stay lag or straying,  Panl is a fine fellow and one Jr am glad to call friend and brother. Circuit court is in session again, but with no case of public moment. I have bseu looking for  Court ney Franklin to put in an appear ance, that I may talk high tariff with him. 1 suppose be will poke f nn at me as he reminds me that the Democrats ill have all tamed to the tar it! .or protection, or Uncle Sam will go broke. Chickens bought In Parmvillc . swept the deoke at tho recent poul try show in Norfolk. Fine place tor raising chickens and children and the champion raiser of ohickcL i- clso the obampion raiser of onildren, Rev. H. H. Hudson, of Charlottes ville, was with ns recently and raised quite two hundred dollars to be used in thé mountain work in Amherst, A rich New Yorker sent him hi cheok for 750 to be used in the same work, provided the chnrohe of the Presbytery would raise a like amount. And, with Mr. Hudson asking for it, there will be no fail ure. A representative Baptist, on the same Sunday, was asking the mem tofts of that church to contribute to the endowment fnnd for Riohm ind College. They want a milion and will, no donbt, get if. These good causes make strong appeals aad make the men and women tbe better for contributing to them. . A fellow-mortal told me recently that be didnt believe in miracles

document.text: yodjf home is as safe as possible. Why not plan to rearrange your storage areas now to provide a safer environment for your children.  Safety Hint for the Week Go fly a kite, but do so safely. Ben Franklin may hive been a genius inventor, and a great kite flier, but safety wasnt his forte. One of thé first rules to remember when flying a kite is  to stay away from any electrical source, notably a high voltage electric line. Electric current . may follow the kite string, shocking or even killing the kite flier, -A second caution is never use wet string, or string that contains metallic fibers. Never use wire. It- is an excellent cqpductor of electricity. Limit kite flying to open area whore the wind will not . carry the kite over electric power lines. If the kite does become tangled in wires, dont try to remove it. yourself. Call your

document.text: yiy C. FRANKLIN, Attorneyat Law,

Yesterday, .March 4, marked the third anniversary of the New Deal. Critics and friends will condemn and praise the record. Only time can finally evaluate the administration of Franklin Delano Roosevelt. Now we can merely offer opinions. Yet, we e -el that honest appraisal is not soi difficut. Roosevelt, like every president and every individ ual has made mistakes. No man in his position could have foreseen the emergence of all issues. BUT mistakes or no mistakes . . . . one  MUST concede that AMERICA IS BETTER OFF TODAY THAN IT WAS WHEN ROOSEVELT BE CAME PRESIDENT. You cant get around that. You out argue human wolf a, e . You  cant harrangue with faits, nor can  you outweigh them with talk of .Liberty Leauge vice presidents. And it is inconceivable that the New Deal didnt have a lot to do with the return of prosperity. It may be true that depressions come
